instances.text: CRWR_V 213-CAP - Introduction to Writing for the New Media

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This section is a part of the Coordinated Arts Program, Media Studies, https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/streams/media-studies/. Students must register for both the Term 1 and Term 2 courses in CAP. 

This course is clustered with the Media Studies sections of the stream seminar CAP_V 100 (please select one of: CAP_V 100-M01, CAP_V 100-M02, CAP_V 100-M03, or CAP_V 100-M04), and CINE_V 100-004. For CINE_V 100-004, please register in the lecture, and one of the following discussion sections: CINE_V 100-D41, CINE_V 100-D42, or CINE_V 100-D43). CRWR_V 213-CAP, and CAP_V 100 do not have any additional discussion sections. Follow the prompts to register in all stream seminars (1), lectures (2), and tutorials (1-2) each term. 
 
For step-by-step instructions, please visit: https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/program/registration/ 
 
If you encounter any issues with registration into CAP, please contact us at support.fyip@ubc.ca 

This is a blended learning course where 50% of the course takes place in-class and 50% online.

instances.text: CRWR_V 213-CAP - Introduction to Writing for the New Media
CSIS_V 200-101 - Critical Engagements in Sexuality Studies

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Further developed speaking, reading and writing; express yourself in a variety of contexts; familiarity with contemporary Danish culture. Improve your ability to express your own ideas and experiences by exploring social and political topics and traditions present in Denmark today.
Cultural topics include: Danish politics and trust (tillid), weather and climate, vacations and holidays, past times and traditions, work culture in Denmark.

Book: Puls 1, Chapter 7 and Puls 2, Chapter 1

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies?
Click here.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
